intro: Merxmuellera setacea, commonly known as the hairy leaved mallow, is a herbaceous plant native to South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its hairy, lance-shaped leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in shaded or semi-shaded environments. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it is not widely known outside its native range.
